Situation1: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story:
I stand behind the register, scanning items and offering polite smiles, my mind half on the clock. The store is quiet until a woman approaches, clutching a blender and looking anxious. “I lost my receipt, but it’s broken. Can I return it?” she asks. I know the policy: no receipt, no return. My manager expects me to enforce it, no exceptions. I see her frustration, and I want to help, but I also know I could get written up if I bend the rules.

My phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s a message from Jamie, my friend from the activist group. “We need more people at the protest—police are here. Can you come?” I glance at the clock. My shift isn’t over, but the cause is urgent. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing on me: the store needs me to be the reliable cashier, following every rule, while my activist friends expect me to show up, to stand for what I believe in. My heart pounds as I look from the customer’s pleading eyes to the phone in my hand, torn between duty and conviction, not sure which demand I can bear to ignore.
